title: Ian Broudie
text:
Ian Zachary Broudie (born 4 August 1958) is an English singer-songwriter, musician and record producer from <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, England. After emerging from the <a href="post-punk">post-punk</a> scene in Liverpool in the late 1970s as a member of <a href="Big%20in%20Japan%20%28band%29">Big in Japan</a>, Broudie went on to produce albums (sometimes under the name Kingbird) for artists including <a href="Echo%20%26amp%3B%20the%20Bunnymen">Echo & the Bunnymen</a>, <a href="The%20Fall%20%28band%29">The Fall</a>, <a href="The%20Coral">The Coral</a>, <a href="The%20Zutons">The Zutons</a> and <a href="The%20Subways">The Subways</a>.
Around 1989, he began writing and recording under the name <a href="The%20Lightning%20Seeds">Lightning Seeds</a>, releasing the album "<a href="Cloudcuckooland%20%28album%29">Cloudcuckooland</a>" through Rough Trade on the independent label Ghetto Records, eventually putting together a live touring band in 1994. <a href="The%20Lightning%20Seeds">The Lightning Seeds</a> achieved great commercial success during much of the 1990s. In 2004, Broudie released an album titled "<a href="Tales%20Told">Tales Told</a>" under his own name. The Lightning Seeds reformed in 2006 and released their sixth studio album "<a href="Four%20Winds%20%28album%29">Four Winds</a>" in 2009.
Early career.
Ian Broudie played in Liverpool's fledgling <a href="Punk%20rock">punk</a> scene in the 1970s. He was a member of the band <a href="Big%20in%20Japan%20%28band%29">Big in Japan</a>, which also featured <a href="Holly%20Johnson">Holly Johnson</a> and <a href="Bill%20Drummond">Bill Drummond</a>. He was also a founder member of <a href="John%20Peel">John Peel</a> favourites <a href="Original%20Mirrors">Original Mirrors</a> in the early '80s, and was credited as a member of <a href="Bette%20Bright">Bette Bright and the Illuminations</a> on their lone album from 1981. In 1983, he recorded and wrote tracks under the name <a href="Care%20%28band%29">Care</a> with vocalist <a href="Paul%20Simpson%20%28musician%29">Paul Simpson</a>; the duo released three singles, including the minor UK chart hit "<a href="Flaming%20Sword">Flaming Sword</a>".
The Lightning Seeds.
Broudie began writing as <a href="The%20Lightning%20Seeds">The Lightning Seeds</a> at the end of the 1980s, scoring a debut <a href="Chart-topper">hit</a> with the song "<a href="Pure%20%28Lightning%20Seeds%20song%29">Pure</a>". To begin with, The Lightning Seeds had just one member – Broudie himself.
The Lightning Seeds produced a selection of well-received <a href="Single%20%28music%29">singles</a> and albums in the 1990s. The albums "<a href="cloudcuckooland%20%28album%29">Cloudcuckooland</a>" (1990) and "<a href="Sense%20%28The%20Lightning%20Seeds%20album%29">Sense</a>" (1992) followed. The latter's song "<a href="The%20Life%20of%20Riley%20%28song%29">The Life of Riley</a>" became the backing music for "<a href="Match%20of%20the%20Day">Match of the Day</a>"'s Goal of the Month competition. In 1994 Broudie created a touring band so the songs could be played live. Their 1994 album "<a href="Jollification">Jollification</a>" is considered by many as the moment the Lightning Seeds arrived as a mainstream band. During the same period, Broudie produced albums for other acts, including <a href="Northside%20%28band%29">Northside</a>, <a href="The%20Primitives">The Primitives</a>, <a href="Terry%20Hall%20%28singer%29">Terry Hall</a> and <a href="Dodgy">Dodgy</a>.
The Lightning Seeds twice took <a href="association%20football">football</a> anthem "<a href="Three%20Lions">Three Lions</a>" (with comedians <a href="Frank%20Skinner">Frank Skinner</a> and <a href="David%20Baddiel">David Baddiel</a>) to <a href="Chart-topper">number one</a>, with different lyrics for the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996">Euro 96</a> and <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">France '98</a> tournaments (Broudie himself is a supporter of <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>; Lightning Seeds album covers and inlays often contain references such as <a href="Hillsborough%20disaster">Justice for the 96</a> and <a href="Liverpool%20dockers%27%20strike%20%281995%E2%80%9398%29">Support the Liverpool Dockers</a>). In the years since France '98, the song has been released multiple times for football tournaments, and now has the unique distinction of being the only song in existence to have become UK No. 1 four separate times with the same artists: two one-week stints in 1996, three straight weeks in 1998 for the remake, and again in 2018 for the original during the World Cup held in Russia.
On 14 March 1997, Broudie was the guest host of "<a href="Top%20of%20the%20Pops">Top of the Pops</a>". Later that year, the Lightning Seeds headlined the Hillsborough Justice Concert, which was held at <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool's</a> <a href="Anfield">Anfield</a> stadium to raise fund for the families in their struggle for justice.
Broudie returned with a new line-up in 2009, releasing the album "<a href="Four%20Winds%20%28album%29">Four Winds</a>," and has extensively toured since with a line-up including old Seeds favourites Angie Pollack (piano), <a href="Martyn%20Campbell">Martyn Campbell</a> (guitar), and Ian's son Riley Broudie (guitar).
In 2021 Broudie said he was working on a new Lighting Seeds album.
Production work.
Broudie worked as a producer with many independent labels including <a href="Factory%20Records">Factory Records</a>, <a href="Creation%20Records">Creation Records</a>, <a href="Zoo%20Records">Zoo Records</a> and Rough Trade, sometimes under the name 'Kingbird'.
Broudie subsequently concentrated on production for other bands, working with the likes of <a href="The%20Coral">The Coral</a>, <a href="The%20Subways">The Subways</a>, <a href="The%20Zutons">The Zutons</a>, French rock band <a href="Noir%20Desir">Noir Desir</a> for their first long album "<a href="Veuillez%20rendre%20l%27%C3%A2me%20%28%C3%A0%20qui%20elle%20appartient%29">Veuillez rendre l'âme</a>", <a href="The%20Rifles%20%28band%29">The Rifles</a> and on a handful of <a href="I%20Am%20Kloot">I Am Kloot</a> songs.
Solo career.
On 11 October 2004, Broudie released his debut solo effort, "<a href="Tales%20Told">Tales Told</a>", which was embraced by critics and fans alike – despite the fact that "Tales Told" saw Broudie move into <a href="folk%20rock">folk rock</a> territory and away from the slick pop sound of The Lightning Seeds. The first song on the album, "Song for No One", featured in the opening episode of the 3rd season of the US TV series "<a href="The%20O.C.">The O.C.</a>"
Personal life.
He lives in London but spends a substantial amount of time writing and recording in Liverpool as his studio was located there. In 2018, he said he was recording in his home.
